Recursive Reasoning: I mentally run a process through several iterations without writing it down.
I track how outputs become inputs across cycles.
I can predict the state of a system after repeated transformations.
I handle nested loops without confusing their order.
I follow branching rules that depend on each step's result.
I notice when a rule should switch based on parity or state.
I simulate feedback loops to anticipate outcomes.
I check base cases before applying deeper recursion.

I can unwind a recursive definition back to its start.
I detect when a process will converge or diverge.
I manage multiple recursion branches simultaneously.
I handle dependencies that appear mid-iteration.
I see when a repeated function needs a stopping rule.

I adjust a rule dynamically when the state changes.

I anticipate how small errors grow across iterations.
I invert recursive steps to reconstruct origins.
I notice when recursive branches converge again.
I juggle several counters without mixing them up.

I check intermediate results against expected patterns.

I apply conditional rules consistently at each depth.
I catch when a rule should stop early to prevent overflow.

I understand how nested rules interact over time.
I can swap rule order to see if the outcome changes.
I detect dependencies that appear only after several steps.
I compress recursive behavior into clear stages.
I balance precision and speed when simulating steps.

Parallel Hypothesis Management: I keep multiple explanations alive until evidence decides.
I mark which evidence supports each idea.
I avoid favoring one hypothesis without justification.
I design tests that separate competing explanations.
I retire hypotheses quickly when evidence contradicts them.
I track confidence without turning it into certainty too soon.
I notice when two hypotheses can both be true partially.
I ask what evidence would change my mind.
I keep notes on why I rejected an idea.
I avoid double-counting the same evidence.
I update beliefs as soon as new data arrives.
I rank hypotheses by how well they predict outcomes.
I separate observation from interpretation.
I spot when evidence is irrelevant to the current choice.
I look for disconfirming data, not just supporting data.
I maintain independent tracks for unrelated explanations.
I consider how evidence quality affects conclusions.
I weigh timing of evidence as well as content.
I check for hidden assumptions behind each hypothesis.
I avoid switching hypotheses without recording why.
I combine hypotheses when they explain different parts.
I ask whether a simpler explanation fits the data.
I keep backup hypotheses ready in case the main one fails.

I create decision trees to test multiple scenarios.
I monitor whether evidence was predicted or surprising.
I separate noise from signal before updating beliefs.
I track which data points are decisive.

I distinguish between absence of evidence and evidence of absence.
I map how hypotheses interact rather than compete blindly.
I check consistency among all surviving hypotheses.

I document thresholds for accepting or rejecting hypotheses.
I notice when adding more hypotheses creates confusion.
I adjust weightings as evidence accumulates.
I watch for confirmation bias in my evaluations.
I practice updating beliefs incrementally.
I keep track of which evidence pieces are dependent.
I pause when evidence conflicts and seek clarifying data.
I avoid overfitting conclusions to small samples.
I prefer hypotheses that make risky predictions.
I design experiments that can falsify my favorite idea.
I share my uncertainty levels transparently.
I handle competing timelines of evidence without confusion.
I downgrade a hypothesis when it keeps needing exceptions.
I check if two hypotheses can be merged into a stronger model.
I keep exploring until one explanation clearly outperforms the rest.
